Award.AwardTitle: Functoriality in Gromov-Witten Theory and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research lies on the interaction between algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. Specifically, it concerns the Gromov-Witten (GW) theory and variation of Hodge structures (VHS) on one side and birational geometry, algebraic cobordism, and mirror symmetry on the other. The main themes of the proposal are the functoriality of GW theory under crepant transformations and the extended functoriality of GW and VHS under extremal transitions (also known as space-time topology change in the physics literature).

Gromov-Witten theory lies in the intersection of many exciting research areas in mathematics and physics. On the one hand, the theory itself has remarkable structures, both established and conjectural. Investigating these structures requires some new insights and technical tools and input from other areas. This provides a lot of interesting problems for classical subjects in mathematics. On the other hand, these new insights and technical tools help to discover deep relations and connections between existing mathematics and theoretical physics, especially the topological string theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gromov--Witten theory is a mathematical subject which has its origin in both mathematics and physics. It lies in the intersection of physics and many branches of mathematics, in particular algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry, representation theory, partial differential equations and integrable systems. Its practitioners consist of both mathematicians and string theorists. Therefore, the study of Gromov--Witten theory often finds new and interesting connections between previous unrelated topics in mathematics and physics.

This proposal studies various aspects of Gromov--Witten theory, but places particular emphasis on the naturality or functoriality problem of Gromov--Witten theory. In particular it explores and gets basic results to the following questions: How does Gromov--Witten theory of a space change when the space is changed slightly? What is the most natural way to describe the changes? How precisely can we describe the changes? These questions are central to our understanding of the geometry of the spaces, but prove very hard to answer. One of the reason of their difficulty is that Gromov--Witten theory packs a lot of highly nontrival information into the very definition of the theory. Any small change in the space can affect the theory in drastic ways. There are, however, ways to repackage these "drastic changes" so that they are recognizable and predictable. Through our efforts, as well as efforts from other groups, we now know much more than we did before. 

Previously, we already knew that when the spaces change in a certain controlled way (called crepant transformation or K-equivalence), suitably formed functions associated to the spaces will exhibit good properties (they are analytic function) and are closely related (via analytic continuation). The previous results are usually not strong enough to be predicative, even though they can be used to explain the facts. What we achieved in this proposal was to extend the previous results (beyond crepant transformation) and make them more predicative. Furthermore, these more precise results may be used to discover new phenomena.

This proposal also provides training grounds for many excellent PhD students who wish to enter this exciting area of research area and for young postdocs who wish to advance their research. The students have been supported to conduct their research and to visit other universities and conferences to learn new techniques. Since our approach involves many advanced techniques and discovers many new phenomena which then generate new problems, these students and postdocs have been trained to master some of these difficult techniques and gone on to successful careers in research and teaching in mathematics.

All results obtained in this proposal are posted online and accessible to the public.
